dc:description:
HYLS1 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive hydrolethalus in 2005 (Mee et al., PMID: 15843405). This is often a fatal fetal condition that results in stillbirth, or death shortly after birth. Prenatal features have been identified as early as the first trimester, and phenotypes include FGR (fetal growth restriction), brain anomalies, skeletal features (like femoral bowing and polydactyly/syndactyly), congenital heart disease, and genital anomalies. The most frequent features of this condition in probands with the founder missense mutation include hydrocephalus, small mandible, polydactyly, congenital heart defects, and respiratory anomalies. Affected probands compound heterozygous for the recurrent missense variant and another missense or nonsense variant have also been reported. Three variants (missense, nonsense) that have been reported in over 40 probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 15843405, 18648327, 34212369) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss-of-function.
There were also two homozygous stop loss variants reported in 2 probands from 2 publications (PMID: 26830932, 36580738), but these were not scored because the phenotype does not fully match that of the other cases  and  and their disease mechanism similarity cannot be confirmed.
This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence (mouse model, drosophila model, expression-level data, interaction evidence, cell culture evidence, functional alteration evidence; PMIDs: 15843405, 19656802, 32509774, 40009365). Homozygous mutant mice exhibit perinatal lethality, brain anomaly, polydactyly, and kidney complications. The drosophila model showed ciliary dysfunction and atypical spermatogenesis in mutants. The gene is widely expressed in mice, including in specific brain regions such as the medulla. HYLS1 interacts with SAS-4 (CENPJ), which is definitively associated with autosomal recessive microcephaly 6 with/without short stature. Other experimental evidence indicates the key role of HYLS1 in centriole stability and ciliogenesis.
 In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Prenatal GCEP on the meeting date 8/06/2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: At embryonic day 15.5, in the head, there is expression in the brain, specifically the telencephalon, midbrain, and medulla. Expression is notable as well in the dorsal root ganglia, cochlea, submandibular gland, and follicles of fibrissae.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse expression

evidence.dc:description: SAS-4 (CPAP or CENPJ) is DEFINITIVE for autosomal recessive microcephaly 6 with/without short stature. Affinity purification of SAS-4 from worm extracts and identification of copurifying proteins utilizing mass spectrometry was done. This effort showed that HYLS1 interacts with SAS-4. The interaction between HYLS-1 & SAS-4 was verified with coimmunoprecipitation utilizing affinity-purified antibodies. Also, centriolar GFP: SAS-4 or GFP:HYLS-1 recruitment in control embryos or embryos lacking HYLS-1 or SAS-4 were analyzed. HYLS-1 recruitment needs SAS-4 but SAS-4 recruitment does not need HYLS-1.
evidence.rdfs:label: Interaction with SAS4

evidence.dc:description: HYSL1 loss triggered centriole defects & asymmetry.
evidence.rdfs:label: DLD1 cells, functional alteration

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded since the model organism/rescue evidence is maxed out at 4 pts.

The mutant animals have a dye-fill deficiency, demonstrating a lack of proper cilia assembly, which is completely rescued using wild-type HYLS1 and partly by HYLS-1 p.Asp210Gly mutant (corresponds to p.Asp211Gly in humans), when expressed from germline promoter (Ppie-1).
evidence.rdfs:label: Cell culture evidence (rescue)

evidence.dc:description: Upgraded due to specificity and thoroughness of evidence.

The phenotypic anomalies, seen specifically in the homozygous mutant mice, not the heterozygous mutants, of having low body weight, polydactyly, cleft palate, and brain anomalies match the human phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded since drosophila models are not the most specific model organisms and even with the downgrade, the experimental evidence is maxed out.

The ciliary defects and impaired centriole elongation seen in the mutant drosophila, suggesting cell division defects and thus growth impairment, matches the IUGR/growth defects seen in affected humans.
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila Model
p.Asp211Gly (homozyg.)
evidence.detectionMethod: mapping to 1 cM region on chr11q23-25, linkage disequilibrium & haplotype analysis of SNP markers; coding regions of candidate genes PKNOZ2, FEZ1, EI24, ITM1, CHEK1, ACRV1, PATE, PUS3, FLG32915, & DDX25 screened

evidence.dc:description: The total score for this proband should technically be 0.6 (0.1 * 2 + 0.4) since the functional evidence is counted just once.
COS-1 cells that were transiently transfected and revealed cytosolic localization of wild-type HYLS1 polypeptides, in contrast to nuclear localization of the mutated HYSL1 polypeptides.

evidence.rdfs:label: p.Asp211Gly & p.Arg205Ter in trans
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: 14 weeks gestation: polymalformative syndrome, significant brain anomalies; bilateral femoral bowing, tibial hypoplasia, lack of fibula

evidence.dc:description:
Downgraded since the mutation truncates protein in only exon and is not NMD-
associated. However, it removes a significant proportion, 31.8 %, of protein.

evidence.rdfs:label: 24 Finnish probands, 16 families, common haplotype
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: All but one proband with information available had polyhydramnios or termination of pregnancy; 21 probands were stillborn, the other 7 died between 1-11 hrs. after birth; all but one with info. available had hydrocephalus; the keyhole defect at the bottom of the skull is a key feature of this condition; other most common features included very tiny mandible, polydactyly, congenital heart defect, anomalies of the respiratory organs

evidence.rdfs:label: p.Asp211Gly & p.Arg221Pro in trans
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: polymalformative syndrome found in the 1st trimester; spinal angulation; external genital anomalies, & anal imperforation; limb malformations were severe
